title: 105_hr2724
content: The Act may be cited as the "Helping Empower Low-income Parents (HELP) Scholarships Amendments of 1997". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to update definitions, including the term 'poverty line' and 'voluntary public and private parental choice program'. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to update definitions, including the term 'poverty line' and 'voluntary public and private parental choice program' which allows low-income parents to choose the appropriate school for their children. SEC. 3. ALLOCATION TO LOCAL EDUCATIONAL AGENCIES. Section 6102(a) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure that State educational agencies distribute at least 90 percent of funds to local educational agencies based on enrollments in public and private schools, with adjustments for higher per pupil allocations to agencies with more children in need, such as those in low-income areas. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to distribute funds based on enrollments in public and private schools, with adjustments for higher per pupil allocations to agencies with more children in need, such as those in low-income areas. States can reserve an additional 15 percent for voluntary parental choice programs if they comply with certain provisions. SEC. 4. USES OF FUNDS. The text chunk discusses the uses of funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including establishing voluntary public and private parental choice programs. The text chunk outlines criteria for voluntary public and private parental choice programs, including location in areas with high numbers of children from low-income families, income limitations for participating families, and scholarship amounts not exceeding local per pupil expenditure. The text chunk specifies that the minimum amount of a voluntary public and private parental choice scholarship is at least 60 percent of the per pupil expenditure of the local educational agency or the cost of tuition at a private school, whichever is lower. Private schools participating in the program can set the same academic requirements for all students. Private schools participating in the program can set the same academic requirements for all students, including those on scholarships. Receipt of funds is not restricted for sectarian purposes, and compliance with all State requirements for private schools is necessary. The HELP Scholarships Amendments of 1997 allow the use of State, local, and private funds for voluntary public and private parental choice programs, with priority given to students previously enrolled in a public school. SEC. 5. EVALUATION. Part D of title VI of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new subsection stating that the section does not apply to states or local educational agencies implementing a voluntary parental choice program. Additionally, a new section, SEC. 6404, is added for evaluation purposes. The Comptroller General of the United States will contract an evaluating agency to conduct annual evaluations of programs established under section 6301(b)(9) according to specific criteria. The agency must transmit the findings of each evaluation to the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General of the United States, in consultation with the Secretary, will establish criteria for evaluating programs under section 6301(b)(9). Criteria include describing program implementation and effects on participants, schools, and communities, with a focus on parent involvement and satisfaction. Educational achievement comparisons will also be conducted. The Secretary will reserve up to 0.50 percent of funds under section 6002 for evaluating programs under section 6301(b)(9), which includes criteria for program evaluation and educational achievement comparisons. The text chunk discusses the applicability of funds used for a voluntary public and private parental choice program, stating that the assistance is for the student, not the school. It also clarifies that the scholarship provided under this program should not be considered income for tax purposes or eligibility for other federal programs. Additionally, it emphasizes that the Secretary cannot control the curricula or administration of schools participating in the program.
